Over the years, shooters have made enemies more complex, included RPG elements, attempted epic tales and had moments where it directly addresses the player. These elements collectively drag down the flow and leave a mess of a game behind, which is unfortunately in this case Shadow Warrior.  Shadow Warrior tries to be a competent shooter and succeeds in that regard but is bogged down by far too much to be worth the effort. At first glance there seems to be a variety of weapons and skills, which can be tailored to the way one wants to play. But the variety comes across rather dull with the tedious weapon upgrade system and the woefully small amount of enemies you actually end up fighting. The enemy behaviour is mediocre at best and downright annoying at worst. Some of the skills and upgrades and completely useless make no sense in context, and a majority of the weapons are not as powerful as we've come to expect, the flamethrower and crossbow in particular.  Moving on from what Shadow Warrior is about, we come to what it's not; the story. In a game that already has a flow so broken, why it felt it needs to have overlong stylised cutscenes and such a heavy focus on the characters, it ends up having many of them with odd behavior and no motivation, with the protaganist being my primary example here. None of the 'witty' remarks made by Lo Wang or his pocket demon are funny, with the humour coming from the fortune cookies you pick up, which are secret items in themselves and have to be sought after to be found.  Speaking of secret items, there are phrases, names, and even sections of the game which reference other games, which breaks the immersion when you notice how out of place they are. As a close reletive to the Duke Nukem games, I can see how this practice would come about, however it obviously didn't learn from Duke Not Finished on how those references aren't funny. Most jarring of all are the arcade cabinets.The aesthetic does feel rather inconsistent at times, although the environments move fluidly from city to docks and underworld to mountains. In addition to that, the levels themselves are breathtaking near the end of the game with the second boss fight being the most memorable part of the game.  Overall, I'm giving this game a thumbs down. The fun and memorable moments of the game are soured by the long and dreary sections between them and the irritating gameplay which just doesn't feel worth the effort. It's not a terrible game, more of a disappointment due to my excitement prior to playing it. For the base asking price, you'll be getting more irritation than it's worth, which is never a good thing.

I cannot recommend this game honestly, I want to like it but I couldn't. The main flaws in this game start small then become larger as you progress further in the game, and it's honestly just personal nitpicks of mine that really discouraged me from playing any further without being more annoyed. Sure the game may look pretty, and may have its moments but it wears thin later on. When I first started playing the game, I noticed some sort of weird jittering movement the protagonist was doing and I tried to find the answer and to no avail there was none. Supposedly, the game doesn't agree with certain video cards despite yours being high end. That, or the game was oddly coded that the ground feels like rugged terrain and Wang is tripping over himself on the floor repeatedly.  Second was the enemies in this game, I didn't mind it at first. In fact I was playing with the sword through the quarter of the game with all the hype in the world dismembering demons, but things started to come into view when I was doing that. The sword isn't that great later on, and the whole 'combinatinos of sword swipes' doesn't really matter at all. If the enemy is blocking, you won't hit them. You can't break their block unless you use a Ki technique, and if you do that enemies will become enraged, zerg rush you, and won't give you much time to react. That's not the worst of it unfortunately, as later on when you keep playing you realize the sword becomes a hinderance late game. An ability that can hit enemies far away isn't reliable at all, so you have to use a gun if you want to progress further. You may ask 'Why should that matter?' Well, the guns aren't good either. You're stuck with the pistol for a good while, the shotgun is terrible, and the uzi is just pure garbage.  Nothing shines unless you upgrade them, and all the upgrades are pretty much useless. Yeah you can dual wield Uzis, but that will waste ammo that you need. The only real good weapon is the rocket launcher, and not because it clears faster because it's the only damn weapon that does significant damage to anything. You'll be stuck on a boss for a long time unless you use the rocket launcher. That is if you hit their weak spot to reveal their real weak spot to even do any damage to them at all. Which leads to my third issue with the game. The enemies.  This game loves to test your patience, so be ready to go through every single room and be forced to clear it out everything in there to progress. Because it'll be a lot of them, at first it won't be much but trust me when I tell you that the amounts get larger and more annoying. When you run out of ammo and have to stab at flying enemies with your sword it becomes apparent that this game really wants you to do either three things; use your sword, burn your ammo, use the crappy gun. As I said, the enemies become more annoying in this game as you progress because it will throw these lets call them super demons at you all the time. First not so much, but late in the game there WILL be a lot of them. You might think it's not a problem, but it really is since three of them are made to be the most inconvient time consuming monsters in the damn game.  They have boss like health almost, take forever to take down unless you want to spam rockets or try spamming your Ki attacks. One will always pull you in unless you chop his arm off, and his ranged attack can ignore corners. Another enemie will spam skeletons, which will continue to spawn forever unless you kill him and add more to the twenty demons in the room that you have to kill. Oh and they become invulnrable unless you kill the skeletons sometimes too. Then there is the icing on the cake of annoying super demons, the ones that you have to hit in the back to hurt in a certain spot. The hitboxes for that one spot is so stupid that you have to get it just right. Otherwise, rockets or any explosives will ignore the damage so it's just better to try hitting them in the back with melee or bullets. However, doing so is a huge tedious process since you have to correctly get them to stun themselves or you won't be able to.  Oh, and the puzzles in this game are annoying. Expect door puzzles to increase too, you have to get Shrine A, B, C (Sometimes all three) to open one single door only to be brought to another. Wouldn't be a problem if I didn't have to clear every single damn room to progress to the next one and kill more super demons just to open one damn door only to be introduced to another god damn locked door. Jokes are very mediocre, I don't mind the protagonist's personality or his sidekicks but the whole comedy of the game is very weak and not that hilarious. Nostalgic value? Eh, it's alright but I really can't recommend this unless you can get it for much cheaper.  /endranting
